description: identification number of household
one of two communities surveyed (Korle Gonno or Abuja)

housing type (block unit: unit in a row of apartments made of cement blocks, wood unit: unit in a row of apartments made of wood, house, compound house: single-story L- or C-shaped house with a multiple units around a shared courtyard, multi-story apartment building, wooden shack, no structure, other)
respondent's relationship to the household head (respondent identified)
gender of respondent (respondent identified)
tenure status (renter, homeowner, or living without payment)
number of years respondent has lived in community
number of adults in household including respondent. Household is described as those "eating from the same pot"
number of children under 18 in household. Household is described as those "eating from the same pot"
number of rooms used for sleeping. Household is described as those "eating from the same pot"
household or respondent owns a business (respondent-owned or household-owned)
home-based, fixed location outside home, or mobile location
type of business (e.g., salon, shop, water vending)
respondent's business uses water beyond typical needs of household (true or false)
primary source of water for business use (packaged water, piped to home, piped to neighbor's home, piped to compound, commercial or public tap, borehole, dug well, spring water, delivered water)
primary source of drinking water (packaged water, piped to home, piped to neighbor's home, piped to compound, commercial or public tap, borehole, dug well, spring water, delivered water)
respondent reasons for using drinking water source (convenience, affordability, availability, temperature, cleanliness, taste, habit or cultural norm, trustworthiness, health, other)
respondent typically purchases individual sachets/bottles, multipacks of these, or both

reason for purchasing preferred package type (storage space in home, cost effectiveness, temperature at time of purchase, availability of money, convenience, size needed for respondent or household, avoiding wasting water by purchasing when needed)
treatment methods of water before drinking
primary water source for non-drinking water (packaged water, piped to home, piped to neighbor's home, piped to compound, commercial or public tap, borehole, dug well, spring water, delivered water)
reason for using primary source of non-drinking water (proximity to home, convenience, affordability, availability, cleanliness, other)
respondent uses at least one source besides primary non-drinking water source (true or false)

additional water source(s) for non-drinking water (packaged water, piped to home, piped to neighbor's home, piped to compound, commercial or public tap, borehole, dug well, spring water, delivered water)
reason for using secondary source of non-drinking water (primary source is not available, primary source is not clean, primary source is crowded, availability of shower stalls, convenient location)
respondent's mechanism for paying for piped water (all respondents use piped water as a primary or secondary source)
daily estimated cost of drinking water for respondent's household
daily estimated cost of drinking water for respondent's household per household member
respondent has struggled to find water before (defined as extreme difficulty to access water) (true or false)
respondent's last time of struggle to find water (e.g., in the last week)
days in a week the respondent typically struggles to find or pay for water
primary reason for past struggles to find water (availability, high cost, distance to nearest source)
respondent's knowledge about tap closures (usually known, sometimes known, expected due to patterns in closures, not known, or no answer)

strategies for coping with water shortage (spending more on the same amount of water, purchasing extra water to store at home, using another source, using packaged water for cooking, skipping cooking, using packaged water for bathing, skipping bathing, closing business due to water shortage, skipping laundry)
respondent typically stores drinking water at home (true or false)
respondent typically stores non-drinking water at home (true or false)
respondent typically does not store water at home (true or false)

if respondent typically stores non-drinking water, types of storage containers (plastic jugs also called jerry cans or Kufuor gallons, uncovered or covered barrels, other covered or uncovered containers)
estimated capacity of storage for non-drinking water in liters
estimated actual stored non-drinking water in liters
identification number
one of two communities surveyed (Korle Gonno or Abuja)
water point type (piped water, borehole, dug well, natural spring)
services available at water point (bathing, public sale of water, toilet)
within a compound or outside compound on a street
year established
owner (household head or member(s), community member(s) outside household
constructor (government or community member)
typical manager(s) of water point (household head or member(s), employee(s), self managed by customers)
estimated storage capacity in liters
average number of daily visits per customer
respondent would use this water to prepare rice (true or false)
respondent's perception of water quality
typical number of tap closures per week
current price of 25-liter jug of water (cedis)
current price of 20-liter bucket of water (cedis)
current price of 30-liter basin of water (cedis)
average price per liter, calculated by averaging price per liter of known prices (cedis)
typical dynamics of water point management during closure (increasing prices, water point likely to close due to low storage, bathing customers have less water than when taps are flowing)
manager adjusts price depending on amount of water needed or familiarity or need of customer (true or false)
price of any volume of water has increased in the last year (true or false)
source of sample for compartment bag test (CBT) supplied by Aquagenx (https://www.aquagenx.com/cbt-ectc/)
results of E. Coli most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample
results of E. Coli most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample - upper 95% confidence interval (CI)
results of E. Coli most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample - descriptive health risk
results of Total Coliforms (TC) most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample
results of Total Coliforms (TC) most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample - upper 95% confidence interval (CI)
results of Total Coliforms (TC) most probable number (MPN) test per 100 mL sample - descriptive health risk
